content: continuing what people were mentioning during today's session ...
I think that having the feeling of being overwhelmed and having people like @nikomatsakis also saying that he feels overwhelmed is totally the way to go
that in contrast of what has said about trying to not overwhelm people that are new

having people like @nikomatsakis also saying that he feels overwhelmed is totally the way to go

It definitely helped me overcome my imposter syndrome :big_smile:
because, this is often how everyone would feel when facing rustc code most of us every single time :joy:
I guess it's a matter of what's each of us goal's but if your goal is to contribute, you will definitely feel overwhelmed most of the time, so why avoiding it? ;)

I feel like I need to read more code and get better at "reading" code. As someone familiar with Rust for a couple of months and knowing nothing about compilers, this was overwhelming :sweat_smile: . But I got something out of it. I planned to read the code and rustc-dev-guide beforehand but unfortunately didn't get enough time. I have some stuff I want to look into more before the next session.
Looking forward to the next one. Cheers!

I couldn't make it to today's meeting unfortunately but I want to confirm that 90% of my time spent reading rustdoc code is either "wtf does this code do" or "oh I remember writing this wow what a terrible hack" lmao

Someone had another nice comment during the session, asking for some context about what we were reading, looking at the bigger picture and where the resolver's place was in that picture. It could be interesting to share some of this information that some participants have, during the reading session. Making sure everyone has at least some idea. Although feeling lost and figuring stuff out bit by bit is definitely "the rustc experience" :) could be nice if we could shorten that period of time for others if at all possible
For sure! I think https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/part-2-intro.html is a good overview of that
